227. McKenzie, (Mrs. Edmund)
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: MRS. EDMUND MCKENZIE
Address: SWIFT CURRENT
Birthplace: N.O.V.A. SCOTIA

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1907
Where did you set up housekeeping? SWIFT CURRENT
Where had you been living before that? N.O.V.A. SCOTIA
For how many people did you prepare meals? TWO
How far was it to your nearest store? TWO BLOCKS
How often could a visit be made to the store? ...........................................

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
ALL GROCERIES SUCH AS SUGAR, FLOUR, OATMEAL BY THE BAG. ALSO BEANS, SPLIT PEAS. OTHERS BY POUND. THERE WERE NO PACKAGED GROCERIES THEN.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? ...........................................
FIVE DOSES
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 POUNDS
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 2 36
How much did you use graham flour? A LOT
Whole wheat flour? YES
Was flour milled locally? NO How far away? What year? ...........................................
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 65¢
What other grain products did you use? CORN MEAL, BARLEY
Cornmeal? YES Whole Wheat? YES Farina? NO
Other? ...........................................
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? NO
How did you grind it? ...........................................

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.
There were no fresh fruits or vegetables with the exception of oranges and no bake shops. Would often have bread sent from Moose Jaw in the cold winter months and freeze it. As the house would get cold at night and chill my dough.

When I came in August 8, 1907 there was not a dealer for sale in the stores. Friends gave me what they had left; and all I could get is can wake grapes. The red ones were not merry tight and the grapes fermented and we had beautiful grape wine but no fruit that year.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

There were no fresh fruits or vegetables with the exception of oranges and no bake shops. Would often have bread sent from Moose Jaw in the cold winter months and freeze it. As the house would get cold at night and chill my dough.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

When I came in August 8, 1907 there was not a dealer in town in the stores and all I could get was can wine grape. The red ones were not merry tiful and the grapes fermented and we had heavy grape wine but no fruit that first year.
